title: 104_s2131
content:
The title of the act is the "Commission on the Year 2000 Computer Problem Act." The act includes findings related to the Year 2000 computer problem. The Congress recognizes a severe computer problem with negative consequences in the year 2000 and beyond. Most computer programs use two-digit dates assuming "19" as the first two digits, leading to issues with recognizing the year 2000. The Congressional Research Service has completed a report on the implications of the "Year 2000 Computer Problem." Each line of code will need analysis or rewriting. The Year 2000 computer problem needs to be analyzed and addressed, with potential costs of up to $600 billion for repairs. The American government, both Federal and State, will bear a significant burden. Six key issues must be tackled, including the history of the problem, costs of code review and rewriting, and the timeline for completion. Agencies at risk of not meeting the deadline must be identified. The Year 2000 computer problem requires analysis and action to avoid potential costs of up to $600 billion for repairs. Key issues include developing contracts with the computer industry for Federal agencies, analyzing the impact on the economy if the issue is not resolved by mid-1999, and providing recommendations to the President and Congress on lessons learned and policies. A bipartisan commission will be established to address the Year 2000 computer problem and ensure all Federal agencies are computer compliant by January 1, 1999. A bipartisan commission will be established to address the Year 2000 computer problem and ensure all Federal agencies are computer compliant by January 1, 1999. SEC. 3. ESTABLISHMENT OF COMMISSION. A bipartisan commission, known as the National Commission on the Year 2000 Computer Problem, will be established with fifteen members appointed by the President and the President Pro Tempore of the Senate. Members will be selected from officers or employees of the Executive Branch, private citizens, or both, with a limit of three members from the same political party. The National Commission on the Year 2000 Computer Problem will have fifteen members appointed by the President and the President Pro Tempore of the Senate. Three members selected by the President Pro Tempore must be from the same political party, while not more than three members selected by the Speaker of the House can be from the same party. The President will designate a Chairman from among the Commission members. The function of the National Commission on the Year 2000 Computer Problem is outlined in Section 4. The National Commission on the Year 2000 Computer Problem is tasked with studying the condition of computer programs related to date fields and the year 2000, identifying problems, analyzing solutions, and providing recommendations to the Secretary of Defense, the President, and Congress. The Commission will submit a final report with recommendations regarding the Year 2000 Computer Problem. The National Commission on the Year 2000 Computer Problem will make recommendations to ensure a smooth transition of government computers from 1999 to 2000. The report is due to the President by December 31, 1997. SEC. 5. ADMINISTRATION.

(a) Executive Agencies must provide the Commission with necessary information.
(b) Commission members serve without extra pay.
(c) Members receive travel expenses while on Commission business.
(d) The Commission is funded by the Secretary of Defense.

SEC. 6. TERMINATION. The Commission, along with all its authorities, will end thirty days after submitting its report.
